children.subject:
I have a bunch of things to say.

First, I think a reduced course load + internship is doable

If you are able to graduate without taking classes fall 2022, I say go for it (without the reduced course load).

You could probably negotiate/leverage the robin hood full time offer when deciding between Robinhood, company x you decide to intern at this summer and any other companies you get into. So, basically it would help vs taking classes like everybody else. 

I say def accept the offer now, and if anything comes up from now until then you can just take back your decision of interning or try to ask for part time hours. Either way you will be good because you will most likely get a full time offer from company x you are interning at this summer (I recommend meta - heard you can promote faster) Good luck !
Did this myself (Robinhood & Stripe), feel free to email me (narang@berkeley.edu) if you want to chat!

history.content: Don't do this. As a person who took some semesters off to intern back to back, I can tell you that you will regret it. Once you're back on campus, you may lose the momentum you once had for your study, and may also hurt your friendships/social circles. There really isn't much difference between the big companies. If you intern in one, you have pretty much experienced it all. Sure, wlb/culture may differ between companies, but that's also true between teams within a single company. A better strategy would be combining big tech + startup experience. As for improving your resume: Once you've gotten one of those internships, you're golden. Enjoy your summer internship and come back to school.

Don't do this. As a person who took some semesters off to intern back to back, I can tell you that you will regret it. Once you're back on campus, you may lose the momentum you once had for your study, and may also hurt your friendships/social circles. There really isn't much difference between the big companies. If you intern in one, you have pretty much experienced it all. Sure, wlb/culture may differ between companies, but that's also true between teams within a single company. A better strategy would be combining big tech + startup experience. As for improving your resume: Once you've gotten one of those internships, you're golden. Enjoy your summer internship and come back to school.

Don't do this. As a person who took **2** semesters off to intern back to back, I can tell you that you will regret it. Once you're back on campus, you may lose the momentum you once had for your study, and may also hurt your friendships/social circles. There really isn't much difference between the big companies. If you intern in one, you have pretty much experienced it all. Sure, wlb/culture may differ between companies, but that's also true between teams within a single company. A better strategy would be combining big tech + startup experience. As for improving your resume: Once you've gotten one of those internships, you're golden. Enjoy your summer internship and come back to school.

Currently a junior, and will be interning at one of (Google, FB/Meta, Stripe) next summer. I recently received an offer from Robinhood, Is it worth taking a gap sem in Fall 2022 to intern there? I don't plan on going to Robinhood fulltime, and instead I will be finishing up the classes I need to graduate + TA'ing. Mainly just wanted to get opinions on whether having another internship will "improve" my resume or if it doesn't matter at this point. Not meant to be a flex and also not here to debate whether Robinhood is an ethical company. Thanks in advance!
history.subject: is it worth taking a gap sem to intern?
